abstracts.cdata!:
This is the environmental assessment for
            the Rural Water and Sanitation Project in Rwanda, which
            address primarily, preventive actions to minimize adverse
            environmental effects resulting from project implementation,
            and prevalent to those communities adopting the same water
            supply system. The choice for water-catchment will be
            assessed following a bio-diversity analysis, taking into
            account the role of natural forests, in safeguarding water
            equilibrium. Mitigating measures call for: 1) installation
            of latrines, or septic tanks, to be located at a distance of
            no less than two hundred and twenty meters from the well, or
            bore-hole, with provision for water testing training; 2) a
            public awareness campaign, to inform consumers on potential
            water contamination and sludge, resulting from construction
            materials. Populations should be aware of this fact until
            infrastructure is stabilized; 3) protective measures will be
            in place on construction sites, enclosing the area with
            barriers, and, regulations will be enforced by government
            officials; 4) herbal vegetation with shallow roots will be
            planted to avoid soil erosion, preferably, gramineous
            species, which do not dry water sources. Recommendations
            include re-enforcement of monitoring, and management testing
            capacities, provision of rain water canalization to ensure
            pasture lands, and, necessary controls to ensure water quality.
